probably not billable, given it was a bug...

The solving of this ticket involved making a functional change (to facilitate the display of single "did you knows"), so I'd say it probably /is/ billable.
If the secondary problem (of errant html appearing in "did you knows") recurs, and is the result of a bug, then - I agree - that issue should /not/ be billable.

Again, though - how was I to know that? If it looks like a bug, and
acts like a bug, how do I know it's an enhancement? That's not to say
we wouldn't have done it, but I need to be able to Decide to do it,
before hand.

content of the second!

Wrt to bug vs enhancement: I hope you don't think I'm trying to get away with calling a bugfix an "enhancement" :-) . According to Janos, the "Did you knows" had been specifically programmed to ignore pages where there was only one "Did you know". I don't know how/why this was specified, or by who, but I'm presuming someone asked for it at some stage. Changing the behaviour of the "Did you knows" to allow single ones to be displayed is thus a feature change.

The /missing/ "Did you knows" that I've just fixed IS a big fix, and I'm not adding it to the billable time for this ticket.

comments.value:
Boiler-plate code that can be inserted into a template to prevent it being sent for translation, perhaps.

Feedback (i.e. "This page has NOT been sent for translation") would also be useful.
Duplicate of #61

Oh wait - not quite a duplicate. 
But I don't want to have 2 separate implementations (for per-page vs per-template) if at all possible.
Costs will be significantly higher if the feedback requirement stays in.
Come to think of it, won't this happen automatically, if the template simply isn't channelled to France? Shame, as it's billable.

In the end, it didn't use /automatic/ template channelling. One reason for this was the horrible template proliferation it was going to cause. Really pointless as there would have been NO difference between (e.g.) "News article" and "News article fr".

Could this functionality simply be implemented by way of a "whitelist" of templates in the "translate" webservice, which raises an exception if the page in question's template is NOT in the list.

Given that amending templates is a dev job, presumably amending the translation webservice would be an acceptable alternative.

This came up again in conversation with Liz today and I think the suggestion of a whitelist of templates (or possibly sections?) in the translate webservice is an excellent idea. 

Liz: could you confirm what would work best from the editorial point of view and we then will have a think about what effort might be required.

My personal view is that blacklisting templates won't work since the
Generic content template is used across so many pages, including some we
need to whitelist.

 

Can we do it on a section / folder basis instead?

 

________________________________
Kieran, could you put a quick effort estimate against this one.

It sounds to me as if the requirement is that we be able to apply a set of fairly arbitrary rules to each page in order to determine whether or not it is allowed to be translated.
My feeling is that the simplest (and probably most effective) way to do this is simply to add some code into the translation webservice that says:
  if (template in templateBlackList or folder in folderBlacklist and/or otherCriteria) {
     throw "This page is not allowed to be translated".
  }
This is certainly the simplest, and most extensible solution. However ... it does NOT provide an easy way for editorial staff (or, for that matter, junior developer staff) to amend these rules on an ad hoc basis. Hopefully this is not a problem. This solution is 0.5 days work.
Anything more complicated would be more: 1-2 days.

That sounds like a pretty good plan.

 

Well, I think we'd be pretty safe in identifying which folders to black
list, e.g. Blog, Culture, Video, etc.

 

Do you have that full list (from all of our discussions on what to
translate)?

 

Liz Goulding

New Media Producer

London Organising Committee of the Olympic Games and Paralympic Games

Direct line: +44 (0) 203 2012 297

Switchboard: +44 (0) 203 2012 000

 http://dev.kitsite.com/kit/folder/photos
Select the "Photos" page, and click on the translation icon (if you don't see it, you might want to log in as kieran/mptt instead).
Clicking on "Send now" sends the page for translation.
However, if there is an error, it gets silently discarded. I'm wondering whether the error could be caught & displayed?
I can customize how the error is returned (E.g. "<error>This page can't be translated</error>") depending on your requirements.

Good start list!

will that work?

However, editors are not allowed to "Send the home page for translation".
I can remove this restriction if you like? It's just that we had it before, so I expect there was a (probably good) reason for it.
Perhaps we should just leave it there, but relax it if it becomes clear that (for some reason) we need to translate the home page regularly.

comments.value: We are interested in testing the positioning of elements on the homepage. we would like to create a second version (call it index2) that switches the position of news/blog tabs and the webcams/videos tab.  There is a new feature in google that can direct half of our traffic to the index2 page and the other to our current page, and we can then test the performance of both!  Can you let me know how much work the swap and new page would be?  Do you have any other concerns with the idea?

Hi Liz,

A/B testing !

Sounds like a great idea, will really give you a feel for what is working before you make any lasting changes, in effect free user testing !

And yes, we can certainly get this set-up for you, hopefully without breaking the bank..

We could do this by altering the existing template to render slightly differentially on a random basis and setting the Google analytics tag as appropriate for each version. But this could mean the existing home page template gets cluttered up and bugs introduced, so..

I think my preferred approach (I think the same as what you are suggesting) would be to keep the main home page as the master and then have an alternative versions (that are *never* manually linked to in the CMS or else we could hit issues when we delete the alternatives) each with a different Google tag to mark the variation and then set-up a redirect on the front end of the site to randomly alternate users between the different versions over a period of time. This keeps our existing master template untouched.

So:

- create alternative home page template, with news/video flipped (we could possibly have more than one variation)
- update google analytics code on both versions as appropriate for GA A/B testing
- create an alternative home page indexb.html that is never linked to in the CMS
- setup workflow to repurposes the manually assigned content from the master home page into the alternative version.
- setup workflow to publish the repurposing when the main version is republished.
- setup a redirect on the front end to seamlessly (ie. hidden to the user) deliver alternate versions on a 50/50 (random) basis.
- test / deploy
- remove redirect / alternative template and pages and update master Google tag on main home page after a given period and revert everything back to normal.

I think being realistic that's probably *a day and a half's work* to get it all set up and tested so we are happy to run with it (and also time spent taking it down afterwards) 

Although we'll leave all the redirects and stuff in place / commented out so you can easily run further tests in future (and much more cheaply, basically only our time spent tweaking the alternative version of the template, which I imagine is no more 0.5 day for an small to medium changes).

Lets have a chat if you need clarification on anything..

Jamie

Jamie,

This all sounds excellent! I'm home today (nasty cold/flu thing) but i'll ring you tomorrow and we can discuss - definitely have a few questions ... just want to make sure I understand all the details!

thanks

Two things I'd need for that:

1. Some kind of access to google web optimizer. I think they do two flavors, one is (if you've created an experiment already) just a link where I can see the necessary tags I need to add to the page.

2. I don't know how far we're on this - A/B experiments are to compare two or more layouts of the page by measuring how successful are the versions. For this, we need to set up a "goal" and basically measure how many of those goals are reached with each version. The goal is in the case of an e-commerce site would be an order confirmation page (the more goals, the more successful the page). In this case it can be trickier, but would be very useful to find a goal that's fairly general and doesn't change a lot. Jamie mentioned the aim of this specific experiment to increase visits to the webcams (page), is it correct?

Also, has someone read the instructions here:
https://www.google.com/analytics/siteopt/ab_checklist?account=1925888 I
think we'll need a 'target page'? (Probably the webcams hub)?

Liz, that's exactly right, we need a success page (or any event that can be treated as success)
The secondary version of the homepage is waiting to go live, so we can get the experiment started as soon as there's a success page or event.

"Figure out which page of your site represents 'success' - it could be a purchase or enquiry confirmation depending on the business type. Once you start testing your variation pages, WO will measure what proportion of visitors who see each variation go on to reach your conversion page. In this way, you'll be able to see which page is producing the best results for you (sales, leads etc)."

If this is about making the webcams more popular, I'd suggest the webcam page as success page - but the more conversion-like, the better.

Ok, cool. For this, I do think the webcam page is the right success
page, though we should definitely think more about what 'success' means
if we try this again in future!

 

Do you need me to set that up, or are you already in GA?

Cool. So. What I think we'd like to do is alter the experiment to now
set the goal page to the news landing page to see if it has an adverse
affect on news if we do switch the news/blog vs webcams/video. Does
that make sense?

 

Liz Goulding

New Media Producer

London Organising Committee of the Olympic Games and Paralympic Games

Direct line: +44 (0) 203 2012 297

Switchboard: +44 (0) 203 2012 000

www.london2012.com  

www.twitter.com/london2012 

________________________________

Right. Could we make an other experiment measuring the news pages as conversions? Yes. Would it be very sensible to compare them with the current results? I think it would be a bit of a moving target. This experiment was to increase the number of visits to the webcams page, and as such it was a half success: there /was/ measurable difference, but it was tiny-tiny. An experience like this should show something like 20% difference between two versions. I'd be overjoyed with 5%.

If, however, as you're suggesting, the aim is to improve the number of -any- clickthroughs (that stay on london2012.com), we could do a completely different experiment saying the conversion is 'user clicks somewhere leaving the homepage and arriving to another page'. This is still not ideal, but we can give it a try.

Danny mentioned there are some KPIs kicking around, and what would be really exciting is to do a testing based on one of those. (Speculation follows:) I suspect there is 'number of new registrations' is on the list. (Oh, what's more, we're measuring the number of registrations and the confirmed registrations as well!) I think there might be some work involved in setting up the funnel properly so you can see where are losing users in the registration process - based on that, we could do some really killer a/b testing to improve the funnel. If you think it might be interesting, I'm happy to detail it in a new story.

The point of changing it to news is to make sure that the 'win' for
webcams isn't too much of a 'lose' for news. If it IS, then we'll need
to make an organisational decision about which is more important! I'm
hopeful that there is no real difference, so we'll then switch the page
to help the webcams, but I want to be sure, first!

 

The registration point is a good one - I've set up a very basic funnel,
but have never really looked much more into it. Do you have suggestions
on that front?
